Show that the tangent line to the ellipse
\dfrac{x^2}{a^2} + \dfrac{y^2}{b^2} = 1
at the point (x_0,y_0) can be written as
\dfrac{xx_0}{a^2} + \dfrac{yy_0}{b^2} = 1

solution.p: First note that by clearing fractions we get b^2x^2+a^2y^2 = a^2b^2. Taking the implicit derivative, we see that 2b^2x+2a^2yy' = 0 so that y' = -\dfrac{b^2x}{a^2y}

Now, the equation of the tangent line can be written as y-y_0 = -\dfrac{b^2}{a^2}\lrpar{\dfrac{x_0}{y_0}}(x-x_0). Simplifying by clearing fractions gives a^2yy_0-a^2y_0^2=-b^2xx_0 + b^2x_0^2. Rewriting as a^2yy_0 + b^2xx_0 = b^2x_0^2+a^2y_0^2 and dividing by a^2b^2 gives
\dfrac{xx_0}{a^2} + \dfrac{yy_0}{b^2} = \dfrac{x_0^2}{a_0^2} + \dfrac{y_0^2}{b_0^2}
Using the relationship \dfrac{x^2}{a^2} + \dfrac{y^2}{b^2} = 1, we conclude that \dfrac{xx_0}{a^2} + \dfrac{yy_0}{b^2} = 1
